clinical_study.brief_title: Reducing Pain and Promoting Neurodevelopment Among Neonates
clinical_study.official_title: Relieving Pain and Promoting Neurodevelopment Among Neonates Admitted in Neonatal Intensive Care Units: A Double Blinded, Multi-Arm Parallel-Group, Pretest Posttest Randomized Clinical Trial

collaborator.agency: Maharishi Markendeswar Institute of Medical Sciences and Research
Maharishi Markandeshwar Medical College and Hospital, Kumarhatti, Solan

clinical_study.source: Maharishi Markendeswar University (Deemed to be University)

brief_summary.textblock:
Repeated painful stimuli causes physiological, behavioural and social, and neurodevelopmental problems in neonates admitted in neonatal intensive care units (NICU). The purpose of this study is to determine the effects of multisensory stimulation and soft tissue therapy on procedural pain and neurodevelopmental maturity among neonates admitted in NICU. The study will be multi-arm parallel group randomized controlled parallel group randomized clinical trial of five days intervention program, consists of multisensory stimulation and soft tissue therapy. The intervention will be given among four groups. Group A will receive both multisensory simulation and soft tissue therapy, Group B will receive only multisensory stimulation, Group C will receive soft tissue therapy only, and Group D will receive regular hospital care. Total 104 neonates admitted in NICU will be recruited through purposive sampling for the trial. The COMFORT behavior scale will be used for assessing procedural pain, and The New Ballard score will be used for assessing neurodevelopmental maturity among neonates. The outcomes will be taken before administering the intervention, and after fourth day of the intervention.
Procedural pain affects the neurodevelopmental outcomes among neonates admitted in NICU. Neonatal physiotherapy plays a vital role in this area. Multisensory stimulation and soft tissue therapy might help in reducing pain and promoting neurodevelopmental maturity. Till now, there is no study available determining the effects of multisensory stimulation and soft tissue therapy among neonates admitted in the NICU.

detailed_description.textblock:
This study will utilize a multi-arm parallel, double-blind (i.e., assessors blind to the condition, and participants recruited in the study), randomized efficacy designed to analyze the effects of soft tissue therapy and multisensory stimulation on pain and neurodevelopmental maturity. The design complies with the requirements of CONSORT guidelines.The study will be conducted in at Neonatal intensive care units, Department of Pediatrics of a tertiary care teaching hospital. Neonatal procedural pain and nurodevelopmental maturity will be assessed before and after the five days of intervention. Procedural pain is the primary outcome measure, and will be assessed with COMFORT Behaviour scale. Neurodevelopment maturity is the secondary outcome measure, and will be assessed with New Ballard score. The measurements will be taken after 24 hours of birth at the baseline and on sixth day of follow-up. The randomization scheme will be based on a permuted block randomization procedure, as it is an gold standard method for allocation participants and prevents selection bias in multi-arm parallel treatment groups.The study will follow double blinding i.e. Participants and outcome assesors will be blinded. The treatment will be given into four groups i.e. Group A (Mulltisensory stimulation and soft tissue therapy group), Group B (Multisensorystimulation group), Group C (Soft tissue therapy group), Group D (routine hospital care). Multisenory stimulation conmbined with soft tissue therapy will be given. The following multisensory stimulation will be provided: Tactile stimulation by gentle stroking in a sequence of chest, upper and lower extremities, back and neck for 3 min. Kinaesthetic stimulation will be given in supine position, consisted of passive range of motion exercises (Flexion and exercises) of both the upper and lower limb extremities for 3 min. Vestibular exercises will be given as a horizontal and vertical rocking for 3 min. Oral stimualtion will be given by gentle stroking over the cheeks, lips, gums, soft palate, tongue, and jaw with index and little finger for 3 min. Visual stimualtion will be given black and white visual stimulation card at a distance of 8-10 min. from the neonate for 3 min., and Auditory stimulation will be given by soft lullaby provided by mother for 3 min. The session will be given once in a day for 5 days in a week.
Soft tissue therapy will be given in face, chest, upper and lower extremities, back and neck of the neonate, consist of stroking, effleurage, fingertip kneading, tapping, and skin rolling. The session will be given for 5 days, 30 min. session once a day.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: Neonates with intravenous cannulation, venepuncture, heel lance, finger prick for a blood test, and Immunisations. Preterm neonates between 32 and 36 weeks of gestation, term neonates between 37 and 39 weeks of gestation will be included in the trail.
Exclusion Criteria: Neonates having unstable vitals, congenital malformations and, with the history of surgery, having inborn errors of metabolism, with seizures disorders, with serious pulmonary complication which requires mechanical ventilation will be excluded from the trail.
